Run Command.description:
Primary on/off point.
Run is used with Bool points where true indicates on and false indicates off. When paired with cmd this is the commanded state of the equipment. When paired with sensor this is the actual status of the equip. If the equipment also defines an enable point then both must be commanded on in order to run the equipment.

Run Status.description:
Primary on/off point.
Run is used with Bool points where true indicates on and false indicates off. When paired with cmd this is the commanded state of the equipment. When paired with sensor this is the actual status of the equip. If the equipment also defines an enable point then both must be commanded on in order to run the equipment.

Enable Command.description:
If exists, represents active / not active state of equipment. This point should only exist if a Run point is present. Point named 'enable' in the BMS often times will need to be relabelled to 'Run'.
Enable is used with Bool points where true indicates on and false indicates off. Equip with an enable should always also define a run point which indicates the primary on/off state of the equipment.

Enable Status.description:
If exists, represents active / not active state of equipment. This point should only exist if a Run point is present. Point named 'enable' in the BMS often times will need to be relabelled to 'Run'.
Enable is used with Bool points where true indicates on and false indicates off. Equip with an enable should always also define a run point which indicates the primary on/off state of the equipment.

Mode.description:
State of equipment operation. 'Plant Mode'. To make things confusing this can be referred to a 'Operation Mode' on some equipment, with the Operation Mode point below referred to as 'HVAC Mode'

This point for a VAV is equivalent to the combination of 'Operation Mode' (Heating/Cooling/etc) and 'Mode' (Standby/Emergency/Purge/Warm-up) from other airside equipment.

Operation Mode.description:
Heating/Cooling/Ventilation. What is the 'AC' or 'HVAC' mode of the equipment.
(e.g.: Cool, Heat, Fan, Standby, Auto, Dry, etc)
This may also be referred to as: 'Coil Mode'

Operation Mode Command.description:
This is a special point typically found on VRFs (and attached indoor units)
This point will be an 'MO' point, and represent the mode command. The 'Operation Mode' point will be type MI and represents the actual mode the equipment is currently in. Typically we would not import this point.
This may also be referred to as: 'Coil Mode'

Occupancy Command.description:
This can sometimes be referred to as a 'Schedule' bv point. Some equipment will have a Schedule (Occ Cmd), Occ Override, and Occupancy Status point. It is preferred that only the Occupancy Status is integrated.
STATUS: Occupied / Not Occupied

Override Mode.description:
For a VFD, this is the 'HAND/AUTO (or Hand-Auto-Off)' Mode.
For airside equipment this may indicate manual control from BMS or special control modes.
Mode(enum)

Override Mode Command.description: Use the 'Override Mode' point unless it is explicitly indicated that it is a mode command point.

Override Status.description:
For a VFD, this is the 'HAND/AUTO' status point.
For airside equipment this may indicate manual control from BMS or special control modes.
Status.

Overridden On Status.description: Point indicates if, due to an override command, an equipment is ON when it would have normally been off.

Overridden Off Status.description: Point indicates if, due to an override command, an equipment is OFF when it would have normally been on.

Emergency Mode Enable Status.description: Binary point indicated emergency mode is enabled

Emergency Mode Enable Command.description: Binary point indicated emergency mode is enabled

Pressure Reset Status.description: Binary point indicating pressure reset mode is enabled

Pressure Reset Command.description: Binary point indicating pressure reset mode is enabled

Economy Mode Enable Command.description: Binary point indicated economy cycle is enabled

Economy Mode Enable Status.description: Binary point indicated economy cycle is enabled

Optimum Start Stop (OSS) Mode.description: Combined mode point indicating whether optimum start/stop logic is activated.

Optimum Start Enable Status.description: Status indicating optimum start routine is allowed to run. (i.e. enter EMW mode)

Optimum Stop Enable Status.description: Status indicating optimum stop routine is allowed to run. (i.e. enter EMC mode)

Early Morning Warmup Status.description: Binary point indicated emw is enabled

Early Morning Cooldown Status.description: Binary point indicated emc is enabled

Night Purge Mode.description: Mode(enum). Mode point showing night purge mode settings

Night Purge Enable Status.description: Binary point indicated night mode is enabled

Night Purge Enable Command.description: Binary point indicated night mode is enabled

After Hours Mode Enable Status.description:
May also be called: After Hours Request | After Hours Push Button
This is a binary on/off point indicating after hours is on/has been requested

After Hours Mode Enable Command.description:
May also be called: After Hours Request | After Hours Push Button
This is a binary on/off point indicating after hours is on/has been requested

Run Request.description: Manual run request flag - typically used with in-zone fans and heaters (this is not the same as an AH request button)

After Hours Mode Runtime Remaining.description: Timer point that controls how long afterhours mode will run for on given equipment. This value will be goverened by a maximum allowable time parameter, and will count down to 0 before disabling the equipment. Typically pressing the AH push button will either set this value to the maximum allowed, or add some time increment to this value per press (up to the allowable maximum)

Connection Status.description:
Communication status of equipment with central controller. Typically used with VRFs.
(0 = Fault, 1 = OK).

Communication Status.description:
Communication status of equipment with central controller. Typically used with VRFs.
(0 = Fault, 1 = OK).

Power Supply Status.description: Does the entity have an online/active power supply

Fault Mode.description: Mode(enum). Indicated fault mode text of unit

Alarm Mode.description: Mode(enum). Indicated fault mode text of unit

Fault Status.description: Indicates unit is in fault / alarm

Alarm Status.description: Indicates unit is in fault / alarm

Connection Alarm.description:
Communication status of equipment with central controller. Typically used with VRFs.
(0 = OK, 1 = Fault).

Communication Alarm.description:
Communication status of equipment with central controller. Typically used with VRFs.
(0 = OK, 1 = Fault).

Coefficient of Performance.description: COP (kW/kW). A measure of efficiency. Also see kW/ton, EER

kW/ton.description: kilowatt per refrigerant tonnages (RT). A measure of effiency. Also see COP, EER

Thermal Power.description:
Thermal power of equipment (kW_r, kW_h, BTU). The is the thermal work rate of the equipment
May be called 'cooling capacity' or 'capacity' calculated point.

Thermal Demand.description:
Thermal demand of locations/systems. i.e. the thermal demand of the 'building' or 'tenant systems' or 'conference room' in kW_r, BTU.
The central plant does work (thermal power) to satisfy the demand (thermal demand).

Electrical Power.description: Native electrical power point for an equipment. (typically there will be a meter instead of this point)

Total Runtime.description: Typically hours. Cumulative time equipment has run for

Total After Hours Mode Runtime.description: Typically hours. Cumulative time equipment has run for in After Hours mode.

Total Start Count.description: Cumulative count of starts for given entity

Electrical Energy Used.description: Non-meter. Some equip have an enery consumption point. Active Energy. This point is likely able to be reset to 0 easily on the equip control.

Lead Select.description:
This is a multi-value point that shows which equipment is in lead position.
This is a simpler version of the 'Stage', 'Staging Mode' setup larger sites have.

Lag Select.description:
This is a multi-value point that shows which equipment is in lead position.
This is a simpler version of the 'Stage', 'Staging Mode' setup larger sites have.

Lead Select Status.description:
Binary status point found on equipment (Pumps, Chillers, Boilers, etc) that indicates whether the equipment in designated as 'lead'.
Commonly found on sites with plant system mode point 'Lead Select'

Lag Select Status.description:
Binary status point found on equipment (Pumps, Chillers, Boilers, etc) that indicates whether the equipment in designated as 'lag'
Commonly found on sites with plant system mode point 'Lag Select'

Stage.description: The stage represents which level of the selected 'staging mode' is active.

Staging Mode.description: Mode(enum). A.k.a 'Sequence'. This corresponds to a program number that dictates which equip turn on for which stage number. So typically the plant will be in a particular 'Staging Mode', which will tell which equipment to turn on based on the 'stage'. Each staging mode will show which equipment is lead, lag, etc.

Stage Up Temperature Setpoint.description: Entering water temperature at which a plant system will stage up

Stage Down Delta-T Setpoint.description: threshold for entering - leaving temp that triggers a stage down of plant system

Operational Stage Count.description: The number of stages supported by this equipment.

Remote Start Status.description: A remote device, such as a time clock which uses a set of contacts, may be used to start and stop a chiller or boiler.

Shunt Trip Status.description:
Special device designed to switch-off the circuit breaker remotely. When energized, a shunt release instantaneously activates the circuit breaker mechanism ensuring a rapid disconnection from the power source.

This device is an optional accessory in a circuit breaker that will be powered externally and can be activated thru PLC and any other relay for protection purposes.

These can be found on chillers to stop compressor operation when non-responsive for a time period.

Some manufacturers use the work 'capacity' instead of load

Night Setback Enable Status.description: A night setback system is used to control a heating system and will lower the room temperature at night. The heating system must always be left on if night setback is used. This prevents the building temperature falling too low and thus avoids potentially damaging condensation forming inside the building.

Night Setback Enable Command.description: A night setback system is used to control a heating system and will lower the room temperature at night. The heating system must always be left on if night setback is used. This prevents the building temperature falling too low and thus avoids potentially damaging condensation forming inside the building.

Heating Modulation Command.description: Silicon Controlled Rectifier (SCR) heaters can modulate heat output by changing time duration of electric input pulse.

Cooling Call.description: Cooling call / flag / request to upstream airside equipment

Cooling Modulation.description:
Typically 0-100%. For inverter compressor equipment (FCU,WPU, HP, etc) this represents setting 'how much' cooling is delivered. 
For cooling as proportion of capacity setpoint - use 'Cooling Load' point.

CHW Call.description: (to chiller/chws) Signal / request / call from airside device to chws

Dehumidification Call.description: typically covered under CHW call, however some equipment may have addition dehum call.

CHW Flow Status.description: Binary point indicating that CHW is flowing
CHW Flow Status.proto: chilled, cooling, flow, run, water, hisMode:sampled

CHW Available Status.description: Binary point indicating that CHW is available to unit if requested. Typically found on airside equipment to indicate chw plant status

CDW Call.description: (to cooling tower/cdws)  Signal / request / call  from airside equip to cdws

CDW Flow Status.description: Binary point indicating that CDW is flowing
CDW Flow Status.proto: condenser, cooling, flow, run, water, hisMode:sampled

CDW Flow Fault Status.description: Binary point indicating that CDW is not flowing. Inverse of status point. Typically found on Chillers.
CDW Flow Fault Status.proto: condenser, cooling, flow, run, water, fault, hisMode:sampled

CDW Available Status.description: Binary point indicating that CDW is available to unit if requested. Typically found on airside equipment to indicate cdw plant status

Cooling Call Enable Status.description: Enough Cooling Calls have been received to enable equipment. Applies to AHUs, Chillers, etc. ( Signal / request / call )
Cooling Call Enable Status.Variation: Multi-zone equipment (AHU, CDWS, CHWS) call aggregation points

Cooling Call Count.description: Number of cooling calls/flags/requests AIRSIDE or WATERSIDE equip has received
Cooling Call Count.Variation: Multi-zone equipment (AHU, CDWS, CHWS) call aggregation points

Cooling Call Count Setpoint.description: Threshold of calls/flags/requests needed to enable equipment
Cooling Call Count Setpoint.Variation: Multi-zone equipment (AHU, CDWS, CHWS) call aggregation points

Cooling Call Demand.description: Number of cooling calls as percentage 0-100%
Cooling Call Demand.Variation: Multi-zone equipment (AHU, CDWS, CHWS) call aggregation points

Dehumidification Call Enable Status.description: Enough Dehumidification Calls have been received to enable equipment. Applies to AHUs, Chillers, etc. ( Signal / request / call )
Dehumidification Call Enable Status.Variation: Multi-zone equipment (AHU, CDWS, CHWS) call aggregation points

Dehumidification Call Count.description: Number of dehum calls/flags/requests AIRSIDE or WATERSIDE equip has received
Dehumidification Call Count.Variation: Multi-zone equipment (AHU, CDWS, CHWS) call aggregation points

Dehumidification Call Count Setpoint.description: Threshold of dehum calls/flags/requests needed to enable equipment
Dehumidification Call Count Setpoint.Variation: Multi-zone equipment (AHU, CDWS, CHWS) call aggregation points

Dehumidification Call Demand.description: Number of dehum calls as percentage 0-100%
Dehumidification Call Demand.Variation: Multi-zone equipment (AHU, CDWS, CHWS) call aggregation points

Humidifier Run Command.description: Only to be used for internal humidifier points. Otherwise model humidifier as equip and use standard control points

Humidifier Run Status.description: Only to be used for internal humidifier points. Otherwise model humidifier as equip and use standard control points

Humidifier Enable Setpoint.description: Humidity level at which humidification will begin

Humidification Modulation.description: Command point controlling the process, typically 0-100%

Dehumidifier Run Command.description: Only to be used for internal humidifier points. Otherwise model humidifier as equip and use standard control points

Dehumidifier Run Status.description: Only to be used for internal humidifier points. Otherwise model humidifier as equip and use standard control points

Dehumidifier Enable Setpoint.description: Humidity level at which dehumidification will begin

Dehumidification Modulation.description: Command point controlling the process, typically 0-100%

Vaporizer Oil Temperature.description: Chiller only. Vaporizer is part of oil filtering & reclaim circuit. The temperature sensor is located in the oil section of the discharge flow from the vaporizer. Oil drains to the sump. (The refrigerant is boiled off and reclaimed in this process)

Condenser Pump Enable Status.description:
**NOTE**
This is a special point only for chillers. The condenser pump is an internal pump to the chiller used in emergency conditions. Typically a single point we have chosen not to break it out into a subpart 'pump'.
The condenser pump will be engaged in two scenarios: 1) Condenser pressure is too high when compressor is off (pump will be used to relieve pressure) 2) Condenser temperature is too low and there is risk of freezing (pump will bring up temperature of refrigerant).

THD Current A K-Factor.description:
K-factor relates the heating effect of a distorted current in a transformer to a sinusoidal current with the same RMS magnitude — it describes a transformer’s ability to serve non-linear loads without exceeding rated temperature rise limits.
The K-factor is equal to the sum of the squares of the harmonic currents multiplied by the squares of the harmonic order.

THD Current B K-Factor.description:
K-factor relates the heating effect of a distorted current in a transformer to a sinusoidal current with the same RMS magnitude — it describes a transformer’s ability to serve non-linear loads without exceeding rated temperature rise limits.
The K-factor is equal to the sum of the squares of the harmonic currents multiplied by the squares of the harmonic order.

THD Current C K-Factor.description:
K-factor relates the heating effect of a distorted current in a transformer to a sinusoidal current with the same RMS magnitude — it describes a transformer’s ability to serve non-linear loads without exceeding rated temperature rise limits.
The K-factor is equal to the sum of the squares of the harmonic currents multiplied by the squares of the harmonic order.

TDD Current A.description: Total demand distortion (TDD) is the per-phase harmonic current distortion against the full load demand of the electrical system.

TDD Current B.description: Total demand distortion (TDD) is the per-phase harmonic current distortion against the full load demand of the electrical system.

TDD Current C.description: Total demand distortion (TDD) is the per-phase harmonic current distortion against the full load demand of the electrical system.

Special alarm points for dedicated sub-systems in equipment that may not always be modelled as a subpart with generic 'alarm' point.

This point is typically on IBZ/Induction Units/FCUs without gravity driver condensate drainage.
